Reading Time: 2 minutesThese days we see a lot of discussion around the way Facebook (does not) take care of it’s user’s data privacy.

Here’re the 2 best sources I’ve found that describe the “problem”.
In fact I don’t think there’s a problem, I’ll explain why in a coming post, but it’s interesting to look at these 2 articles to understand what people are talking about.

In this diagram The New York times give a view on the 50 settings with more than 170 options that are available to manage privacy on facebook.

<div>
</div>

<div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;">

</div>

</div>

<div>
  <div>
    In this&nbsp;series of images <a href="http://www.mattmckeon.com/about.html">Matt McKeon</a><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-family: Corbel, Helvetica, 'Andale Mono', 'Trebuchet MS', sans-serif; font-size: 35px;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-family: 'Times New Roman'; font-size: medium;">&nbsp;shows the evolution of privacy default settings over the years (from 2005 to now).</span></span>
  </div>
  
  <div>
    It&#8217;s amazing to see how user&#8217;s data are more and more public by default everyday&#8230;
  </div>
